Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Absorption engineering of optical and thermal hyperbolic metafilm patterns

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to explore ultra-broadband on-chip light trapping mechanisms for efficient photon/thermal management, energy harvesting and enhanced heat-to-photon conversion. The promising applications enabled by this work could have enormous long-term impact on our national energy, environmental and sustainability needs. Integrating research with education is a high priority in this interdisciplinary effort, which links nanotechnology, computational electromagnetics, optoelectronics, electrical engineering, and energy research. This program will deliver state-of-the-art nanophotonic technologies to students, and instill in them the skills, values, and broad perspectives necessary for success in the global market place, for leadership in complex, multidisciplinary projects, and for a lifetime of continued learning.


The approach is to develop a patterned hyperbolic meta-film that can efficiently absorb broadband electromagnetic waves. Large area multi-layered metal-dielectric films will be investigated to develop a planar thin-film absorber with tunable absorption profile from optical to thermal domain, which will create new regimes of optical/thermal physics and applications. The proposed large area patterned hyperbolic meta-film would represent a major breakthrough in our understanding of absorption/emission engineering of slow-light chips, and holds promise for developing novel applications for energy conversion and thermal management devices. This very high-index effective medium holds much more density of states than low-index media and therefore has greater potential for efficient heat-to-photon conversion, which, unfortunately, is NOT naturally available. Therefore, being able to create a high index metamaterial will provide a technological foundation that will revolutionize a variety of photonic/thermal applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Absorption is one of the important intrinsic features of materials. Efficient optical absorbers are highly desired on the micro/nanoscale where they can play a significant role in preventing crosstalk between optical interconnects on integrated photonic chips. This project performed an early stage study to explore the potential to engineer the absorption property of patterned metamaterial surface structures. By cascading graded patterns, the absorption band can be extended and manipulated, which will create new regimes of optical/thermal physics and will impact a broad range of military technologies ranging from efficient thin-film photodetection elements, microbolometers for IR imaging, to compact thermal absorbers/emitters for thermal energy collection/conversion, and radiative heaters/coolers.  In this 1.5 year EAGER project, we obtained the following outcomes:

1. We analyzed the absorption band engineering potential for wo-dimensional hyperbolic metamaterial patterns. Polarization-insensitive and angle-insensitive super absorption was realized experimentally. This study resulted in a publication entitled 'Broadband absorption engineering of hyperbolic metafilm patterns' published in Scientific Reports, which was featured by several public media including Live Science. Com (Fig. 1) and selected as the cover image of the latest NSF Proposal and Award Policies and Procedures Guide (Fig. 2). 

2. Most super absorbing metamaterial patterns rely on top-down expensive lithography methods. To address this challenge, we developed low cost, large area lithography free methods to realize spectrally tunable and high performance super absorber from visible to thermal spectral region. These studies resulted in three publications published in Nanoscales [highlighted by Advances in Engineering.com (Fig. 3)] and Appl. Phys. Lett. 

3. We further developed nanocavity enhancement mechanism and demonstrated strong absorption resonance in ultra-thin Germanium films and 2D material monolayers. Specifically, we demonstrated that over 70% absorption was obtained within 1.5-nm-thick Ge films and over 30% within graphene monolayers. These studies resulted in three publications in Advanced Materials (highlighted as the Frontispiece Article, Fig. 4) and Optics Express. 

4. Based on the localized field enhancement supported by lithography-free metamaterial super absorber patterns, we demonstrated a broad band universal substrate for SERS. In contrast to conventional SERS substrates that can work for individual wavelengths only, the new braadband super absorber can work for any excitation wavelength within the absorption band. This unique feature will enable new sensing applications for chemical/biosensing of trace molecules. This study resulted in a publication in Adv. Mater. Interfaces [featured as the Front Cover Article (Fig. 5) and several public media including Science360 and Materials 360]. 

This project resulted in one PhD thesis and several invited talks in international conferences.
